intro: Sinapis pubescens var. brachyloba, commonly known as the short-stemmed mustard, is a herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and alternate leaves that are lance-shaped and pubescent. Its flowers are usually yellow or pale yellow, blooming in early spring, and it produces small, elongated pods containing several seeds. This variety is often found in disturbed soils and is used in traditional medicine for its potential anti-inflammatory properties.
